metadata.author: Jiuwang Yu, Lu Wang, Lidao Bao
metadata.title: Exploring the Active Compounds of Traditional Mongolian Medicine in Intervention of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Based on Molecular Docking Method
metadata.abstract: <p>In this study, a research strategy combining network pharmacological analysis, protein docking and molecular docking virtual computation was adopted. It was found that phillyrin and chlorogenic acid could block the combination of 2019-nCoV S-protein and ACE2 at the molecular level. Both can be used as potential inhibitors of 2019-nCoV for further research and development. </p>

introduction: Exploring the Active Compounds of Traditional Mongolian Medicine in Intervention of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Based on Molecular Docking Method

In this study, a research strategy combining network pharmacological analysis, protein docking and molecular docking virtual computation was adopted. It was found that phillyrin and chlorogenic acid could block the combination of 2019-nCoV S-protein and ACE2 at the molecular level. Both can be used as potential inhibitors of 2019-nCoV for further research and development.

summary: Exploring the Active Compounds of Traditional Mongolian Medicine in Intervention of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Based on Molecular Docking Method.
<p>In this study, a research strategy combining network pharmacological analysis, protein docking and molecular docking virtual computation was adopted.
It was found that phillyrin and chlorogenic acid could block the combination of 2019-nCoV S-protein and ACE2 at the molecular level.
Both can be used as potential inhibitors of 2019-nCoV for further research and development.

Introduction: Exploring the Active Compounds of Traditional Mongolian Medicine in Intervention of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Based on Molecular Docking Method.
Results: <p>In this study, a research strategy combining network pharmacological analysis, protein docking and molecular docking virtual computation was adopted.
It was found that phillyrin and chlorogenic acid could block the combination of 2019-nCoV S-protein and ACE2 at the molecular level.
Conclusion: Both can be used as potential inhibitors of 2019-nCoV for further research and development.
